note.p:
Salutation from letter of 27 June 1862
Salutation from letter of 27 June 1862
Letter Call no.

Salutation from letter of 27 June 1862 In some ways, William B. Anderson's short letter of 27 June 1862 to his wife, Mary Louisa, typifies the twenty-one letters from William to Louisa that survive in the collection of the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. It addresses three of the four broad topics about which he repeatedly writes to his wife during the summers of 1862, 1863, and 1864: managing domestic affairs and sustaining familial bonds when family members are separated for long periods by great distances; the rhetoric and logistics of mid-nineteenth-century correspondence; and the economic, logistical, and physical challenges of the riverboat business, especially on a waterway as critical as the Ohio River in the midst of the American Civil War (in other letters, Anderson also reflects more broadly on the uncertainties, vicissitudes, and suffering faced by civilians and soldiers alike in wartime).

However, this letter is also unique. All but two of the letters were written from Cincinnati, a thriving center of commerce on the Ohio River approximately halfway between its source at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and its confluence with the Mississippi River a mile or so south of Cairo, Illinois. The remaining letter in the collection was written from St. Louis, Missouri—though Anderson mentions writing from Louisville, Kentucky and Nashville, Tennessee as well. This letter was written from Pittsburgh, William and Louisa's home town. Presumably, he had been visiting his family and had expected to leave Pittsburgh by the Friday in late June when he wrote the letter; he writes to inform his wife of a delay.

As the collection in general reveals, delays were common, caused variously by negotiations over freight, water levels on the river, mechanical difficulties, and various military complications. Arrangements regarding freight seem to have kept Anderson in Pittsburgh overnight on June 27. He wants to secure a full load before leaving Pittsburgh because he "cannot depend upon getting any freight below here." He takes the opportunity to ask Louisa to send down "the Can of milk and 2 jars of lard and my clothes and overcoat." The definite article stands out: the Can of milk. One wonders whether, in his habitual haste (on which he often blames poor spelling and handwriting), he has simply rushed off and forgotten these items, and Louisa has sent him a note asking what she should do with them. In any case, in his haste to send her instructions, he crosses out the next two lines of his letter and recomposes them. Characteristically, the life of a riverboat captain seems frenetic.

It is also worth noting that he arranges to convey a note to his wife via "some one on the Shore at Shousetown." While the Andersons clearly handled much of their correspondence through the U.S. mail (he mentions post offices several times, and the collection includes one stamped envelope), they often convey both messages and goods through intermediaries traveling by rail or river.

Anderson's closing request constitutes something of a refrain in the letters. He asks Louisa to call on a Mr. Russell (probably John Russell, a local merchant) in order to collect money owed him, noting that he must meet his obligations on the crew's upcoming payday. Aside from suggesting that riverboat captains had to watch their cash flow carefully, this request reminds us that Louisa played a key role not only in caring for the Anderson household, including their four children (a fifth would be born in 1865), but also in tending to their business interests. Though we have only William Anderson's side of the correspondence, the letters reveal many details of Louisa's everyday life as well.

It is Louisa, presumably, whom we have to thank for initially preserving the letters, probably for the very common, personal reasons to which David Levy alludes in Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age: "In the privacy of our own homes we are likely to hold on to any number of treasures: cards, letters, and notes written long ago, photographs, scrapbooks filled with mementoes from an earlier era. We can't throw them out, even if we can't say why. We may look at them rarely or not at all, yet still it is somehow comforting to know they are there. It's as if something of importance is embedded in their very substance. This has less to do with their information content per se than with the emotions they evoke and the personal relationships they signify and embody" (96–97). The Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University purchased the letters in part because they fit into a larger goal of acquiring materials that reveal the "common man's view of great events," and war letters are one focus of that larger effort (Smith). The collection as a whole, and the letter of 27 June 1862 more specifically, should also prove interesting to business historians and students of letter writing in American culture (Hewitt). The passing of time has made the everyday information in the letters newly valuable, though the letters also retain the power Levy speaks of to evoke the emotional fabric of everyday life, especially when it becomes frayed in the course of great events.

place.desc: In his letter of June 16, Anderson notes that he did not write to Louisa during a previous stop in Louisville, KY.

projectDesc.p: This edition represents a series of letters that William B. Anderson wrote to his wife, Louisa, at the time of the Civil War. During the war, Anderson piloted steam ships along the Ohio River, carrying freight and passengers alike. At this time, letter writing was the most effective means of communication, and the only way to keep domestic affairs in order.

The collection of letters penned by Anderson was purchased by the Ohio State Rare Books and Manuscripts library. They purchased the letters in an effort to increase their collection of wartime letters as well as documents that better illustrate the life-world of the historical periods that the letters were written in.

The reason for digitizing these documents is that the editors are trying to make these documents as easily accessible to as many people as possible. These letters may be of intest to historians interested in the Civil War, the Steamship Industry, or even postal historians. These potential readers were given the most careful consideration in designing the digital texts. The hope is that by making these annotated and edited documents available on the world wide web, that the documents will be "streamlined and tailored in the service of ever greater efficiency" (Levy 69). Hopefully, the rich media and annotations provided will help make these documents more easily understood while the technology itself makes them more widely available to interested audiences.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.
The XML and XSL files related to this edition are all available in the KB.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

person.note: Mary Louisa Fischgens (1837-1911) and Capt. William B. Anderson (1822-1897) were married September 15, 1853 in Cincinnati, Ohio. They had five children.

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his Wife, Louisa, 16 June 1862
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: William B. Anderson writes home to his wife, Louisa, from Cincinnati, Ohio. He is hauling Coal Boat men from Louisville, Kentucky. While in Cincinnati, Anderson visits his mother-in-law, the 'old lady,' as well as family friends. During the dry, dusty, June weather, a fire breaks out near the Ohio River and Third St, destroying several houses. He opens his riverboat up as an improptu shelter for the fire victims, even filling the typically unoccupied Ladies' Cabins. Anderson closes the letter by inviting Louisa to accompany him on his next trip to Cincinnati.

div.p:
I did not write to you
from Louisville on account of our
short stay there & thought we would
beatbeet the Mail up, we will leave
here tonightto night we had a good trip
of Coal boat men up here from Louisville
but our prospects are poor for a trip
of either Freight or passengersPassenger up, though
upon the whole we make a paying trip
I will finish this half sheet just
before we start & then I can tell you
more

We have laid over and will leave this
Evening we are getting all we want I have
just been down to see your motherMary Louisa Anderson's mother.. she is not
very well Today sends her respects EllaElla is unidentified.
was at school I did not see her. There was
a large fire down between Third st and The river
yesterday just one squaresquear above the old lady's"ladys
and burnt a lot of Old Houses & other property
we have had all our rooms but 3 in
the ladies Cabin full since last night but
we have not up till this time had a lady
passenger on our boat the old lady says
she would like to have you pay her a
visit so if you think you would enjoy
a trip I will offer you an invitation
twe will if no accident get up about
Saturday & leave again about Tuesday
todayto day it is all most suffocatingly hot
and the dust is so thick that I cannot
scarcely see the buildings along the wharf
& I think we must surely have a gust soon
I will stop for I expect to spend Sunday
with you & the small ones 4

tell Mary McNamee5 that WM was over
with us last evening and that he is well
we will leave about 4 or 5 PM this
Tuesday EvengEvening
